question.text:
A conducting bar of length L is free to slide on two parallel conducting rails as shown in the figure

Two resistors R1 and R2 are connected across the ends of the rails. There is a uniform magnetic field B→ pointing into the page. An external agent pulls the bar to the left at a constant speed v.

The correct statement about the directions of induced currents I1 and I2 flowing through R1 and R2 respectively is :

options.text: Both <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> are in anticlockwise direction

Both <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> are in clockwise direction

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is in clockwise direction and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is in anticlockwise direction

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> is in anticlockwise direction and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> is in clockwise direction

solution.text:
Given, the external agent pulls the bar towards left. According to Lenz's law and Fleming's right hand rule, there will be a motional EMF generated in the bar. The right-hand rule tells us that the magnetic force on positive charges will be in downward direction and the electric equivalent circuit can be drawn as shown below.

So, I1 is in the clockwise direction and I2 is in the anticlockwise direction.
